title.narrative: OUTPUT 1.1.4: Prevention of Mother to Child Transmission of HIV (PMTCT) AND CHILDREN AIDS

description.narrative: By 2025, service providers and community actors have strengthened capacity to provide quality Prevention of Mother to Child Transmission of HIV (PMTCT) services to pregnantand lactating women and to provide routine screening, treatment, and follow-up of exposed or infected children and adolescents., which contributes to Fast-Track The End Of Hiv/Aids, Fast-Track The End Of Hiv/Aids (Covid), Operations Support To Programme Delivery. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Advocacy And Public Engagement, Fostering Innovation And Use Of New Technologies, Harnessing Power Of Business And Markets, Innovation, Operational Support To Programme Delivery, Partnerships And Engagement: Public And Private, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building, Systems Strengthening To Leave No One Behind. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: By 2025, pregnant women, new-borns, children, and adolescents, especially the most disadvantaged, make full use of integrated quality services in health centres and at the community level.

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: By 2025, service providers and community actors have strengthened capacity to provide quality PMTCT services to pregnantandlactating women and to provide routine screening, treatment, and follow-up of exposed or infected children and adolescents.

description.narrative: During 2021 the CO supported 19 priority districts in eight regions to eliminate mother-to-child transmission of HIV (eMTCT) and care for HIV-exposed/infected children and adolescents. By year-end 82 per cent of children born to HIV-positive mothers had received antiviral (ARV) prophylaxis within 72 hours, 81 per cent of children under two months of age received testing and treatment and 98 per cent of HIV-positive women received ARV treatment. In 24 health districts supported through the family testing approach, 91 per cent of children and adolescents aged 0-19 years identified through the approach received testing, encouraging scale-up of these approaches. | Status:Partially met | As-of Date:18/01/2022
